Programs for upgrading employee skills and transition assistance programs
column13: Our 24-month Dump Truck Operator Traineeship Program, which offers entry-level employment and a nationally recognised CERT III in Surface Extraction Operations, continued to attract new talent in FY23.
column20: Employee training programs, Talent attraction, Certification pathways

column6: Programs for upgrading employee skills and transition assistance programs
column13: The Frontline Leader Training Program is a three-day course for existing and high-potential leaders, focusing on self and team leadership, strengthening commercial acumen and incorporating safety leadership concepts with STRIVE Values behaviour. The program seeks to build leaders' capability to resolve issues quickly, build trust with their teams and encourage open, two-way communication.
column20: Leadership development, Team leadership, Safety integration

column6: Programs for upgrading employee skills and transition assistance programs
column13: With the Werris Creek Mine ending in FY24, we are implementing a tailored program to support our employees affected by the change. Data We actively engage in open and transparent consultation with our employees and contractors. We support employees by having one-on-one career conversations to understand their ambitions and preferences to explore redeployment opportunities at our other mine sites.
column20: Workforce transition support, Redeployment opportunities, Consultation

column6: Percentage of employees receiving regular performance and career development reviews
Diversity of governance bodies and employees
column13: Our progressive and holistic Women's Leadership Development Program aims to inspire and equip high-potential and senior female leaders with the confidence, skills and drive to step up in the business. The annual eight-month program draws on performance psychology and behavioural science to help participants build resilience, increase visibility, improve self-awareness, and develop influencing skills and personal action plans.
column20: Women's leadership development, Diversity inclusion, Career advancement

column6: Diversity of governance bodies and employees
column8: Whitehaven Success at the 2023 NSW Women in Mining Awards
column13: Hollie Sampson, an Aboriginal Community Relations Officer in Whitehaven's Gunnedah office, took home the prestigious Exceptional Young Woman in Mining award, an incredible achievement and the first time a Whitehaven employee has claimed the prize. Leonie Newton from Whitehaven's Maules Creek Mine was also recognised as a finalist in the Outstanding Trade, Operator or Technician of the Year category.

column7: We respect and support our employees' right to freedom of association and collective representation. Whitehaven has nine collective agreements across the business, and approximately 56% of our employees are covered by enterprise agreements.

column13: We have two Native Title Agreements: the Narrabri Underground Native Title Agreement and the Maules Creek Native Title Agreement. We also have a Cultural Heritage Management Agreement with the Barada Barna people, the Traditional Owners of the land in Central Queensland, where the Winchester South Project is located.
column20: Aboriginal community relations, Indigenous employment, Reconciliation action

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column8: Employment of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples
column13: Company-wide, 10.5% of our workforce identify as Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander, compared with 8% in FY15 when we adopted our first Reconciliation Action Plan. This outcome is a testament to the strong teamwork between our Recruitment and Aboriginal Community Relations teams and the efforts of our crucial contractor partners.
column20: Native title agreements, Cultural heritage management, Traditional owner engagement

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: For the Vickery Extension Project, we have committed to a voluntary target of 10% Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander employment, mirroring the commitment we have fulfilled at Maules Creek. A Board decision on the commencement of full-scale operations at Vickery will be made in late 2023.

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: We run initiatives to promote roles to local Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. It includes recruiting Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students for our Trainee Operator Program and working with the Clontarf Academy and other education partners to encourage local students to consider a career in mining.
column20: Local community, Trainee Operator Program, Clontarf Academy

column6: Operations with significant actual and potential negative impacts on local communities
column13: Whitehaven opened its doors to the community by hosting an open day in April 2023. The open day at the Boggabri Showground showcased our technical and operational teams and heavy mining equipment and featured various fun activities.

column6: Operations with significant actual and potential negative impacts on local communities
column13: In FY23, we continued to engage with a range of stakeholders on the intention to seek approval for the continuation of the Maules Creek Mine, which will support the continuation of operations to approximately 2043. an application to seek approval to extend the haulage hours from Tarrawonga Mine to the Gunnedah CHPP.

column6: Operations with significant actual and potential negative impacts on local communities
column13: An application to modify the closure and rehabilitation plan for our Werris Creek Mine to provide better long-term environmental outcomes. The Winchester South development is progressing through the Queensland Government's approval process.

column6: New suppliers that were screened using social criteria
column13: In FY23, we completed due diligence on our key third-party labour-hire providers through a comprehensive self-assessment questionnaire. In all cases, we found no evidence of modern slavery practices in our supply chain.

column7: In line with our Political Contributions Policy, we may make political donations approved by Whitehaven's Managing Director that comply with applicable legislation. In FY23, we made zero disclosable political donations.

column13: In FY23, we assessed our cybersecurity approach against NIST and identified some areas for improvement. As a result, in FY24, we intend to expand our cyber capabilities and commence several improvement initiatives, starting with an external operational technology audit.

column6: Substantiated complaints concerning breaches of customer privacy and losses of customer data
column13: Third-party cybersecurity specialists continuously monitor the security of our system, conduct regular penetration testing and assess security controls. Cyber response plans are also simulated and integrated into our Crisis Management response teams.

column6: Substantiated complaints concerning breaches of customer privacy and losses of customer data
column13: A robust information technology security framework and backup data infrastructure support Whitehaven's operations. However, computer viruses, unauthorised access, cyber-attacks and other similar disruptions may threaten information security and impact operational systems. Whitehaven manages this risk by investing in systems to prevent such attacks and undertaking staff training programs.
